pros: Decent benefits but not excellent. Can have a decent work life balance if you are lucky enough to have a supervisor/manager with reasonable expectations.
cons:
More often than not work expectations are unrealistic and administration expects more from positions than they are capable of handling. 

Due to staffing shortages and extremely high turnover, employees are often required to cover positions and responsibilities WAY outside of their job scope without compensation for indefinite amounts of time.

No clear feelings of direction, leadership, structure or vision from administration. 

In most cases there is extremely little to no structure, policy, procedure, guidelines, or expectations for employees in their roles. You are expected to feel your way, blindfolded through your job and learn through correction what the expectations are.

job_title: Student Worker Farm Hand in Bozeman, MT

Best job I ever had.
cons: I wish it would have paid more, I could have done this forever if it did but someone has to pay the bills.

review_title: Good employer, naive to cost of living
pros: Enjoyable atmosphere among academics in the field with reasonable support systems in place for employees. The benefits package in my early-career position included respectable health insurance that I have not yet had matched in subsequent jobs.
cons: There is arguably nowhere in the state with higher cost of living or stiffer real-estate market within a small town, and the base wages as they were defined during my tenure (~ $11/hr) were effectively sufficient to break even in a shared home with multiple roommates. Cool place to be and work a job, but you'll be paying for the priviledge.

job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in Bozeman, MT
pros: Montana State is fortunate to have a large number of faculty members that are at the tops of their respective fields. Most research projects that we don't have the resources for in our lab, can be accomplished through collaborations with other labs on campus. The University also does a good job of fostering a supportive and inclusive environment for people of all walks of life, despite Bozeman's placement in a very red state.
cons: As the cost of living increases in Montana, and especially Bozeman, the University system has failed to keep pace with compensating its employees. This has pushed numerous University employees out of the city-proper, to locations where they're required to make increasingly commutes. The University's solutions to rapid growth have also been frustrating (i.e., horizontal growth rather than taller buildings), and parking permits are outrageously expensive.

review_title: MSU doesn't take care of it's people
pros: Great research community. Many of the faculty are working on extraordinary projects. There are many friendly people around campus willing to give extra to the students.
cons:
Overall, the culture of the employment side of the University is terrible. When it comes to the University treats its employees like 'grawlix'. They have no regard for the well-being of staff or faculty and especially adjuncts. 
My station was in the math department which is an absolute 'grawlix' show; to the point that they are consistently losing high-quality tenured professors.

review_title: An incompetent organization ran by clueless leadership paying the lowest salaries in town.
pros:
Job security: Once you get past the probationary period, its very difficult to get fired. 

The folks working in the colleges (staff and faculty) are fairly easy to work with.
cons:
President Waded doesn't care about the staff at all. 

MSU / UIT will pay you the absolute lowest amount of money they can. When I originally applied for this position, the UIT HR person (no longer works there) was planning on offering me BELOW the starting salary. I was told this information by another person in HR that I trust. 

They are losing people left and right for dumping more work on them with no additional pay. When people do get offers somewhere else, nothing is done to retain them.

UIT (central IT "on" campus) has no idea what is going on on campus. The majority of them are off campus in a rented building and make decisions based on what they think is right for campus without ever talking to faculty and staff. 

They have no idea what the needs of researchers, faculty or staff have because they don't actually work with them. There are a small group of "embedded" IT folks on campus (that's where I worked) and they have a much better idea of what the needs of the campus are because they actually work in person with faculty, staff and researchers.

Other than horrible pay, incompetent leadership and being surrounded by "typical" government workers you also have to pay to park on campus as an employee. You have to pay for the "wolf" pass or higher to have a guaranteed spot on campus. The cheaper options oversell the lots so unless you get to work 15 minute or more before 8am and don't leave on lunch, you can spend 15 minutes driving around trying to find a spot.

I honestly cant think of any reason to work at MSU or especially in IT at MSU. They will say "the benefits are great" and that's actually not the case anymore. So many other places are much more competitive and at a minimum, pay significantly more.

review_title: No Respect for the People Who Do the Teaching
pros: Adjunct teaching offers a great deal of flexibility, but...
cons: ... the administration has no respect for adjunct faculty, even though they do the vast majority of the undergrad teaching. In 2020, President Cruzado got a 50% pay raise. Adjunct faculty got a 2% pay raise. And 2% of nothing still is basically NOTHING.

review_title: Meaningful work, but underpaid and overworked.
pros: In my department there was really great mentorship and networking. My direct supervisors were great advocates for me and my day-to-day coworkers built a strong sense of community and mission. Within my department, there was a lot of trust and ability to self-manage which worked with my professional style.
cons: Overall higher administration is very exclusive and inaccessible. Visible divide between upper management and the many lower-level employees. Extremely difficult to get pay increases and most staff are very underpaid- especially considering how expensive it is to live in the community. Burnout was very real across the entire campus.

pros: Good people and colleagues, flexibility in time
cons: Salary was significantly lower than anywhere else

review_title: You will be underpaid unless you make yourself indespensible and then begin interviewing elsewhere.
pros: Benefits, are provided if you work more than 20hrs/week. Area has a lot to offer if you can afford it.
cons: Dysfunctional leadership structure contributes to problems of underpayment and understaffing of dedicated and necessary workers while unnecessary and overpaid positions in administration continue to expand. There is no effective check and balance against administrative bloat and the quality of education for students suffers. Turnover in entry level faculty and staff positions that make the university function is a huge problem as these workers find their pay is inadequate for the cost of living in Bozeman. This continuity problem is exacerbated by problems with ineffective workers not being let go while effective workers workloads continually expand. Merit is nonexistent. The quality of education is dubious at best and getting worse.

cons: Pay is on the lower side for student employment

review_title: Must have a passion to help students
pros: Everything is centered around the student and trying to give them the best experience possible.
cons: Low pay and long hours.

job_title: Smarty Cats Tutor in Bozeman, MT
pros: Decent pay. Can set your own hours every semester, so super flexible.
cons: Probably should tutor a couple classes, otherwise it can be slow.

pros: fun, great, super cool, neat
cons: under paid, no money, no dinero

pros: Strong engineering pedigree, respected in industry.
cons: Aging labs and equipment, funding goes to expansion rather than updating.

review_title: Research Associate with Bachelor's Degree and 3 years experience earned less than local fast food joints
pros: Sensible work culture with friendly atmosphere
cons: Abysmal hourly wages in the context of high-cost-of-living community

pros: Good coworkers and environment are great

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Great policy analysis education program
cons: Very flexible research assistant work

pros: Beautiful Campus, wonderful colleagues, good community.
cons: Salary is not really nationally competitive, but decent. High cost of living in town.

pros: Flexible schedule and relaxed setting

Many ways to connect with others. 
Opportunities to move up.

pros: Fun, Energetic, Reliable, Great Cultural

pros: Great leadership and friendly working environment
cons: Low budget and low technology implementation

pros: Great location for higher education
cons: cold winter. it lasts 6 months or so

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Bozeman, MT
pros: Location of campus and services
cons: Extremely long hours and days.  No set schedule.  Poor communications from supervisors

pros: Bozeman is a great place to live and MSU has some very quality researchers and good facilities
cons: The university doesn't prioritize research properly, provide the right support for research staff (grad students up to PI's)

pros: Great way to gain experience in a lab environment.
cons: Low pay and sometimes depends on if you receive a grant or not for pay.

pros: Great place to get grounded

job_title: Associate Professor in Great Falls, MT
pros: Faculty support is outstanding. Great place to live and work.
cons: None that I can think of :)

job_title: Strength and Conditioning Coach in Bozeman, MT
pros: Good benefits for their employees

job_title: Full Stack Web Developer in Bozeman, MT
pros: I work with amazing people that all care about what they do

pros:
people are nice
location is unbeatable

review_title: I've enjoyed being a student here
pros:

-caring professors

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Bozeman, MT
pros: Bozeman is beautiful and a paradise for nature lovers
cons: The housing market is very competitive and rents are extremely expensive.

job_title: Extension Educator in Great Falls, MT
pros: Faculty of MSU. Support from fellow agents and administration.
cons: Isolated in county you represent.

review_title: Greedy Upper Administration Makes Teaching Here More Difficult Than It Should Be
pros: Interesting, open-minded colleagues, most students are good, kind people (though many aren't adequately prepared for college), beautiful campus surrounded by mountains (don't miss the naturally heated duck pond!)
cons: Low pay is not commensurate with cost of living in BZN; upper administration (president, provost, and minions) not particularly interested in good teaching or scholarship unless it brings some form of status with it

pros: Mid size university with ability to easily collaborate in a beautiful state
cons: In many ways the university is under resourced

pros: Very high level of accessible undergraduate research and proactive faculty.
cons: Limited remote instruction and struggle to transition.

pros: Great location. Many fantastic faculty.
cons: Low pay for NT faculty positions, and below average for tenure faculty.

review_title: Low wages. Good entry job to gain experience

Wages considerably below livable wage 
No incentives for performance

pros:

Homework can be done on shift

job_title: Research Assistant II in Bozeman, MT
pros: Really pretty, neat research, lovely benefits

pros: The employee benefits are great

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Environment great for outdoor activity. Interesting research depending on advisor
cons: High cost of living. Variable support from administration

pros: Good people and flexible hours
cons: Sometimes initial pay is not high

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros:
Very Flexible with hours
Interesting Work
cons: Can be a bit much to do while at school

pros: Montana State is an awesome school and employer.
cons: Montana State does not have any cons that I can think of.

pros: Excellent professional faculty and staff
cons: Pay is low all across the state.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Billings, MT
pros:
Friendly work environment. 
Easy payment processes.
Helpful support staff.
cons:
Can be stressful. 
Dependent on who you work with.

job_title: Field Technician in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Schedule flexibility, but depends heavily upon your research advisor.  Research facilities are for the most part very good, but it depends a lot on what you're specializing in.  They have a nice gymnasium and good views of the mountains.
cons: Again, depends upon your research advisor and department.  Graduate courses for the geology program are supremely lack-luster.  Advisors are good/mediocre/bad depending on what you specialize in.  Secretarial and other supporting staff are severely underpaid and do not seem to do their jobs very efficiently (honestly, why would they at $12/hour in Bozeman?).  Geoscience research equipment is overall not well-maintained, again mostly due to underpaid staff and inaccountability.   Several tenured professors are retiring and not being replaced.  Overall camaraderie amongst students and staff needs a lot of work.  I seriously wish I had not have come here for grad school.  Do yourself a favor and look elsewhere.  Buy yourself a pair of ice cleats/Yaktraks for winter if you do decide to come because they do not salt the sidewalks or roads here, and prepare for your car battery to die in the winter.  Classes will never be cancelled due to the weather.

pros: Benefits are great. Some nice perks such as having a cafeteria, coffee shops, and a gym on campus. Some really great people to work with too.
cons: Some really not great people to work with as well. A lot of managerial level people should not be managers. There seems (in some departments) to be a culture of just promoting people through the ranks even though maybe the person being promoted isn't right for the job (they've just been there for a long time). As a result, it's hard for someone early or mid-career to find a good mentor for others to learn from. Poor growth opportunities and poor pay for this area as well.

review_title: MSUB considerable more enjoyable then City College
job_title: Everyone Does Everything in Billings, MT
pros: Great benefits available at day 1 and much shorter wait for vacation and sick leave then in the privet sector.
cons: ALL UPPER MANAGEMENT. For those of you who are looking to do "advising," "recruitment," "enrollment," or "student life," at City College. Stop considering the job, there is a reason they can't keep a full staff, that is why their turn over is unreal. Everyone does a little of everyone else's jobs, and the micromanaging is unlivable. One position had 3 different people in 1 year! One position had a new person EVERY YEAR. Unrealistic expectations and even if you pass the schools goals for anything you may not get to keep your job. The so called "upper management" is not worth any of your trouble!

pros: I worked with some really smart people, and by and large I was left to my own devices.  I was given problems that needed solving, and after a while I was selecting the problems that needed solving.  Very satisfying work.
cons: It's a public university, and one of the largest in Montana.  So it has all the bad parts about working for the government and working for a large company all rolled into one.  It was nearly impossible to get fired (not that I tried), but it was likewise nearly impossible to get more than a cost of living pay increase either.  The salary was well below market for a person with my skills, and they have a hard time retaining skilled people, especially in tech fields.

pros: Great benefits for being an RA, nice to live on campus and have room/board taken care of.  Great to be a part of a community in the RA role.
cons: Poor management, Residence Life management would say one thing but act much differently. Poor life balance, expected to be an RA 24/7, and sometimes not allowed to be yourself. The job takes up a lot more mental space because you live in the residence halls and only get 10 chances a semester to escape for a night.

pros: The best thing about working for MSU-Bozeman is working with intelligent people helping others to learn and get ahead with life. The students provide a varied and interesting environment to work within.
cons: It's difficult to get promoted as there are no direct promotion paths for staff. The only way seems to be through changing jobs. Raises only happen when the legislature passes them and then they are given across the board, not by merit.

review_title: The working conditions and atmosphere is shown in a positive, does not reflect the actual working condition.
pros: Open spaces, close access to local amenities. community, breath and width of what the university offers for family members.
cons: In many departments there is a culture of Elitism if you do not have a Master degree you are treated as working slaves. Wages have not kept up with inflation or living costs of the valley. No room for upper mobility for anyone who is not of value to managements greater image for the university.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: I was employed as an RA in the college of engineering as a masters student. I was happy to receive a tuition waiver and living stipend. I found the stipend to be adequate to meet all my needs, and even received a raise for my last several months of work. I was happy with the education and support I received.
cons: Work conditions for RA and TA positions vary greatly depending on the department and professor one works with, so while I was happy I know some students don't have the same experience.

review_title: Great students, co-workers, and opportunities to be challenged!
pros: Working with students and student staff every day. Every day is a new experience and brings new challenges in the job. I have learned a lot about my personal leadership and supervision styles and I feel blessed that I am able to make a positive impact on those around me. Bozeman is a beautiful town with awesome people.
cons: Most jobs at MSU are faced with a large work load and below average pay. You need to love your job and Bozeman in order for these challenges to be worth it.

review_title: Montana State University allows fantastic student employment opportunities.
pros: As a student, Montana State allows for a diverse networking system. In addition, the management ensures that students prioritize school before all else  and after completing responsibilities for their job to use spare time, such as for a desk clerk, to work on class work. For students that work late night shifts that are often quiet this is an ideal setup.
cons: Some of the shifts that students can work especially the late night security shifts are long for people who have classes during the day.

review_title: Fun job to get you through college
job_title: Front Desk Clerk in Bozeman, MT
pros: Chill environment. Can do homework on shift when it's slow. Nice people. Easy commute. Flexible hours.
cons: The pay was a little low, but it was most people's first jobs so they didn't know any better. If you had to take time off, it was a hassle to find a sub to replace you, and if you couldn't find someone to take your shift, that was on you to work, that was rare, but it happened.

pros: Talented faculty across the board, and a very positive environment. A lot of push for growth and continually improving research activity throughout the department.
cons:
MSU is small for a RU/VH Computer Science department. As a consequence,

There are only one or two professors per research area, and some focuses, such as data management, human computer interaction, and architecture, have no faculty.

There is no guaranteed financial support for graduate students, so assistance, although usually available, can on occasion be uncertain. A limited number of Teaching Assistant positions are available from the department each semester, and Research Assistant positions are funded through individual professors from grant money.

pros: Montana State University has great staff and working environment. The supervisors and colleagues are very supportive and make working in a team enjoyable, motivating one to achieve a successful goal
cons: Some of the benefits could be improved and the management can do a lot better with that. Compensation is between minimum to nothing, which makes it look as if the work done by employees is not appreciated.

review_title: Oppressive work environment where micromanaging abounds and subversive management style is the norm.
cons:
- Very cold and austere community.
- Training consists of sophomoric professional development seminars like, "How to Work with Difficult People."  Obviously those do not help, since so many employees at MSU are difficult to work with.
- Office culture is that if you weren't born in Montana, you'll have a hard time making new friends. 
- Campus culture is so polarized that rarely do faculty fraternize with staff and rarely, unless one is in the "clique," do staff engage with other staff. Not welcoming to new incoming employees.
- Career advancement opportunities are non-existent unless you "know" someone and are able to secure a higher-level, better paying position before it is made public.  One is unable to advance within the department they work. One must continually jockey around campus finding new jobs to receive higher pay and advancement.
- Company values?  Oxymoron.  Most employees keep their heads down and say nothing for fear of being reprimanded for expounding on something creative and different or out of the realm of anything the faculty propose, most of which have never worked in private sector.
- Successful managers embrace creative environments; MSU views that as a threat. As a result, one is constantly striving for excellence in mediocrity.
- Poor manners and lack of etiquette, despite the fact that faculty and upper admin believe they are to-the-manor-born.

job_title: Laboratory Teaching Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Flexible environment in a beautiful, outdoor setting. The students are very hardworking and represent a remarkable diversity. The salaries are generally the highest in the Bozeman area.
cons: Because MSU is the biggest employer in the area by a large margin, there aren't clear standards for professionalism or accountability. Upper echelon staff prefer to keep things going smoothly in order to preserve appearance of "top tier research university". However, there is no investment in the future. Staff and faculty members are often alumni of the university, so fresh perspectives are needed.

review_title: The MSU Local Government Center is THEE BEST place to work!
pros: Seriously the best people to work with. Amazing. Energetic. They understand that a great work environment is essential for a successful business.
cons: I was a student worker, so the pay is not fantastic and you have a limited number of hours you're allowed to work. Not a problem during the school year but during the summer you can still only work part time. As a student worker you also don't get benefits or bonuses and such.

review_title: Campus dining halls - good Freshman-Sophomore year college job
job_title: Dining Hall Employee in Bozeman, MT
pros: Slightly above minimum wage pay, simple to get hired and keep position.  Great college job, especially if you live in the dorms.  The managers are great about working around classes/tests, though it is your responsibility to find people to cover your shifts.  It was fine when I needed to take a test and no one could cover though.  Free meals when you work.
cons: Be ready to get a bit dirty and smell like burgers when you come home, particularly for dishroom.

pros: The best reasons to work at MSU-Northern would have to start with the students.  Being a small institution allows us to have more personal interaction with the students.  I also enjoy the team atmosphere in Student Services.
cons: The bureaucracy of working in a State Funded institution that is underfunded is the largest downside.  Additionally, the inflexibility and complacency of a good number of our faculty makes for a difficult working environment at times.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Decent pay for the area, great professors in the department to TA for but you get out what you put into being a TA. Very little working hours, leaving more free time to focus on schoolwork.
cons: They no longer provide university health care for TA' s, some lab sections are from 8-10 PM which can be quite late for a lot of graduate students (homework can be very time consuming)

review_title: A great opportunity and amazing experience, would definitely recommend working here as a student if at all possible.
pros: Worked in the Immunology and Infectious Diseases Department. Had a great opportunity to really learn analytical assays and experiments with very knowledgeable and experienced people. My hard work and dedication paid off and my research results were eventually published; of course with the help of my wonderful PI and graduate advisor.
cons: No real cons associated with MSU. Got paid a decent salary and as a student, there was no better way to gain valuable work experience.

pros: Supportive work environment, beautiful setting, research orientation, community supportive of the institution.  Great colleagues, active student population, outdoor recreation opportunities, and supportive of individual growth
cons: Montana State University does not have a pay scale in line with other states although the cost of living in Bozeman is quite high.  It is especially challenging for entry level employees

review_title: Best group of people to work with
job_title: Student Administrative Associate in Bozeman, MT
pros: I work in the Office of Institutional Equity. The people who work in this office are great! They are really friendly and supportive, and will do whatever they can to help me as a student coordinate my work schedule around class and meetings. I have learned so much about EEO and employment laws through my experience in this office.
cons: I can not think of any. As I said, for a student this position is great since they are all so helpful and supportive.

job_title: Assistant Manager, Strand Union in Bozeman, MT
pros: I worked on campus during school, and there was no better place to be.  The hours were flexible, the pay was reasonable and I had a great boss
cons: Sometimes got stuck at school during holiday breaks. The summer was really slow and boring. You got paid not much more for alot more work at a manager level

review_title: I live the hard life of a graduate research assistant but I'm getting paid to improve myself. I cannot complain.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Varied assignment that often improve skills introduced in the classroom. The compensation is almost lavish for the young single male.
cons: Sometimes overwhelming. Grading can be the bane of one's existence. There isn't much choice in regards to what tasks must be completed. Faculty sometimes assign crushing amounts of grading.

pros: Work outside, constantly exercise just by doing ones job, good area to cool off in summer, or warm up in winter, many different types of projects to work on, don't have to do the same thing every day, works with ones schedule to fit in hours
cons: bad communication from the office to the manager, below average pay for the type of position

pros:
- Flexible work hours
- Not required to work holidays
- Can do homework during slow times
- Pay is competitive
- Most coworkers are great
- Only have to work two to three weekends a semester
- Perfect location
- Pretty good discounts
cons:
- Management can reign a little heavy for no real reason
- Communication needs work in almost every department

pros: The culture and colleagues are a great reason to work at the MSU Bookstore. Everyone works in a team effort and our friendly. The staff makes the bookstore successful.
cons: Changes are occurring affecting the general overall low employee moral. There is a resistance to the change creating a bad vibe among the employees reflecting in the quality of work.

pros: A very pretty and helpful community of folks on campus. I have enoyed the students and the faculty very much during my work there,
cons: The salary is terrible and the amount of upward movement is very limited. A lot of people leave as soon as they find something better

job_title: Help Desk Clerk in Bozeman, MT
pros: Worked around classes and schedule when they could. Coworkers were helpful and a good group of people for the most part.
cons: Some students would get obnoxious with us if they were frustrated with the problem they were having. I guess things like that happen anywhere you go.

pros: Great geographic environment, and Bozeman is a very community oriented city.
cons: MSU has ABYSMAL salaries for both classified staff and faculty, with almost no opportunities for advancement, and for classified, no merit increases at all.

pros: there is a great group of people who work there. They always make it fun. It works around your schedule really easily.
cons: It's a food service job so it's pretty much what you expect. Hot, messy, and quite disorganized at times. Very high turnover rate.

review_title: There are better Land Grant Universities to work for
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Provides great networking opportunities for outside of academia, and opportunities to collaborate professionally.
cons: Dedicated faculty, but the employee services are out of date, infrastructure is dated (no handicap access), and administration is dysfunctional.  Working there you feel like the university is taking steps to expand while cutting corners in administration and services -it shows.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: High concentration of extremophile scientists all at one university. The compensation is pretty good considering Montana has a much lower cost of living than a coastal area.  Lots of opportunities for cross disciplinary collaboration given MSU historical geographic isolation. A surprising number of the top scientists choose to live in Bozeman, making MSU an incognito research powerhouse.
cons: Disjointed departments that do similar work don't always connect well

review_title: Summer Internship Experience at College of Engineering
pros: For the 10 weeks spent there, I have to say that the lifestyle was excellent, opportunity for learning was excellent, and the entire faculty was laid back, but capable.
cons: For the department of Electrical and computer engineering, there can be a bit more research opportunities, but I am sure this changes constantly.

job_title: Senior Cook III in Bozeman, MT
pros: MSU chips in over 1000 a month for benefits.  They offer 6 free credit hours pending management approval.  Production style work so fairly slow paced.
cons: Inexperienced leadership, promotions based on politics and cronyism, paychecks once a month, parking (expensive and rare), passive aggressive management style,  unionized and ineffective.

pros: It is Montana, not much is expected of us, and our president is high profile.
cons: Hiring practices corrupt, less and less insurance every year, and too many students.

review_title: Excellent Place ..but a little laid back
pros: Small school, so everything is easy paced . Campus housing is easily available and parking is plentyfull. Most people are locals and you build a great relationship working
cons: Small school..so its difficult to get recognition and break out. have to perform much higher than others to get nationally recognized

pros: It looks good for your resume, flexible hours and work schedule. Also a laid back environment and generally nice employers.
cons: This job does not always pay very well, you might also need a grant which would help for money. Sometimes not many hours.

review_title: An easy place to get an on campus part time job for students
job_title: Dining Hall Employee in Bozeman, MT
pros: They work well with your schedule and hiring process is quick. Easy to get a pay raise if you work for more then one semester.
cons: Low pay for possibly hard amount of work. I loaded and washed fruit which is harder manual labor but was still only paid 8.5 bucks an hour.

review_title: Research Assistant - Health Communications - Public Education
pros: The flexibility of schedules, the level of mentor-ship, and the hands-on experience of the formidable challenges in academic research.
cons: The university cap on the amount of hours one can work and still be considered part-time makes it virtually impossible to sustain a position.

review_title: A great way to make some money while helping students do better in school.
job_title: Smarty Cats Tutor in Bozeman, MT
pros: You get to make your own schedule. Most students are very grateful and enjoyable to work with. There are also opportunities for drop-in tutoring.
cons: You are limited to 20 hours a week.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Billings, MT
pros: It is easy to get involved. There are some very dedicated employees. Chancellor, Provost, and Vice-Provost are excellent. I teach small classes. We focus on helping students be job-ready.
cons: We have struggled with retention of students. Some faculty don't want to baby students, but that translates into lack of caring.

job_title: Ph D Candidate in Bozeman, MT
pros: It is located in beautiful town Bozeman. Lot of out door activities to do. Great place to live and work.
cons: Leadership is good, and they treat their employees very well. More over the place makes you to stay there for ever.

pros: good benefit, low work intensity. they have a pretty good health insurance plan, everyone is happy about it. close to yellow stone.
cons: small town, the food is very simple here, very limited variety in the city, people are too relaxed when they are working , the ordering system is wired.

review_title: Adjunct Instructor at MSU... know what you are getting into....
pros: MSU has wonderful students and Bozeman is a great town.
cons: Our department's reluctance to treat NTT adjunct instructors well, including: lack of communication, low pay, no vacation, and little respect.

review_title: Very enlihtening experience into the mechanism of state schooling.
pros: Great people, lots of opportunities for a person to make serious advances in their chosen career field.  Overall very happy.
cons: As a state run university, you are subject to the oversight of the montana state board of regents based in helena.

pros: under moderate pressure, nice co-workers, many opportunities overall it is a very good place to start your career.
cons: pay is a little low and management need to be improved to meet the increasing working speed.

pros: Professional development opportunities, friendly atmosphere with sense of community, great benefits, including tuition fee waivers.
cons: Low pay partly due in part to poor support from State Legislature.

pros: Everyone is nice and friendly. Benefits are good. Work life balance is dependent upon what department you work in and who your manager is.
cons: Human resources is a joke and the wages are awful for such an expensive town.

review_title: Enjoyed campus activities. Good health plan, but staff salaries are low and advancement opportunities limited
pros: If you love learning, there are lots of opportunities for a staff person to take classes and attend educational events.
cons: Low pay. No bridge between classified positions and professional jobs.

job_title: Residence Life Staff in Bozeman, MT
pros: Acitvely seeks the needs of students
cons: Not as interested in caring for the needs of employees (esp student employees.)

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Bozeman, MT
pros: Location, Class size, diverse research
cons: compensation, school does not care about grad students

review_title: Good people, great experience with work-study!
pros: While working as an audio/video technician I enjoyed being able to contribute to the university and gaining some experience. My manager was nice and helpful if I needed any questions answered!
cons: None I can think of!

job_title: Adjunct Nursing Instructor in Great Falls, MT
pros: Good people as co-workers, flexibility.  I found that they were able to work with my schedule to facilitate their schedule.  Pay was good.  Fully enjoyed the experience.
cons: I had no adverse or negative working experiences with this organization.

pros:
* A great team to work with
* The managers are available to help all the time
* Casual environment
cons:
* There is some age difference between management and employees that can  result in difficulties 
* Tech level is low

pros: Could take whatever shifts fit your schedule no set hours. Work active and not boring
cons: I wouldn't always get as many hours as I wanted each week.  MSU pays monthly

pros: The hours are flexible, the bosses are great, and the projects are fun.
cons: It's hard to say, but I think sometimes the workload would come in chunks of time, which made it hard to spread out.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Freedom to manage my own time.
cons: Low pay for sky rocketing rental rates in Bozeman, MT and no health insurance. Not treated as employees of the university.

review_title: I have taught communications at this university for 16 years.
pros: I have great work mates, and I like helping students.
cons: We almost never get raises, and when we do, they are small.

pros: lots of free food provided by the full time staff. accommodating hours to work between classes
cons: Not many employee motivation factors. Student employees are sometimes treated like children rather than adults.

pros: I went in with almost no experience and now I know much more! Fun environment and good team members.
cons: Sometimes there was not enough work and could lead to very boring, tedious tasks.

pros: Good benefits, relaxed atmosphere typical of a university setting.
cons: Politics inherent to a university campus get in the way of common sense progress in the IT department.  The pay could be a little more competitive.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Great outdoors, nice small college town, frendly people
cons: work experince varies vastly from dept to dept. some dept have very little funding and are too boring to work in

pros: flat organization, slow pace work environment, small work groups, outdoor recreational opportunities.
cons: faculty don't care, no mentorship, too expensive tuition, poor programs.

pros: Love the mission of the land grant University, challenging work, great management, the tools we use are great, and flexible with schedules.
cons: Parking is a little challenging on campus.

review_title: Stable but no room for innovation.
pros: Stable, state funded, interesting problems, big organization with lots of opportunities.
cons: Bureaucratic nightmare, actively discouraged innovation, understaffed

pros: Good school, particularly in some disciplines. Outstanding community and environs, great school system and good place to raise a family
cons: Retirement benefits not up to snuff with other similar institutions

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Good benefits, Some great people. Beautiful campus, decent workspaces.
cons: Like all large organizations, you can feel underappreciated and underpaid.

job_title: Administrative Associate II in Bozeman, MT
pros: Flexible Hours, great coworkers, great work environment, all staff is friendly and helpful
cons: Office space is limited, terrible base pay with limited growth potential

pros: Extremely flexible scheduling, not too demanding or difficult
cons: Little organization and cleanliness, passive avoidant management

pros: As a student, working on campus is extremely convenient, and undergraduate involvement in research projects is stellar.
cons: The university is notorious for low wages for student employees

review_title: Greate place to gain experience working in research labs while studying.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Bozeman, MT
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn research techniques and contribute to multiple research projects.
cons: Some of the equipment is a little outdated.

pros: This is the only place in Bozeman for individuals with higher degrees.
cons: The environment is red and do not understand anything blue.

job_title: Graduate Admissions Coordinator in Bozeman, MT
pros: Good benefits, state employee, great students
cons: Wages low for cost of living in the area, you're an under-appreciated cog in a machine
